would appear that Amberley has one hobby in life, and it is chess.  Not
far from him at Lewisham there lives a young doctor who is also a
chess-player.  I have noted his name as Dr. Ray Ernest.  Ernest was
frequently in the house, and an intimacy between him and Mrs. Amberley
was a natural sequence, for you must admit that our unfortunate client
has few outward graces, whatever his inner virtues may be.  The couple
went off together last week--destination untraced.  What is more, the

luggage with a good part of his life's savings within.  Can we find the

artistic side of crime he might have found something here to study.

did I ever refuse one of her requests?  Was ever a woman so pampered?
And that young man--he might have been my own son.  He had the run of
my house.  And yet see how they have treated me!  Oh, Dr. Watson, it is

Little Purlington is not an easy place to reach, for it is on a branch
line.  My remembrance of the journey is not a pleasant one, for the
weather was hot, the train slow, and my companion sullen and silent,
hardly talking at all, save to make an occasional sardonic remark as to

So Mr. Amberley and I found ourselves on the roadside in what seemed to
me to be the most primitive village in England.  We made for the
telegraph office, but it was already closed.  There was a telephone,
however, at the little 'Railway Arms,' and by it I got into touch with
Holmes, who shared in our amazement at the result of our journey.

fear, my dear Watson, that there is no return train to-night.  I have
unwittingly condemned you to the horrors of a country inn.  However,

was not undeserved.  He had grumbled at the expense of the journey, had
insisted upon travelling third-class, and was now clamorous in his
objections to the hotel bill.  Next morning, when we did at last arrive

"If they are not worth more than the last ones they are not of much
use," said Amberley, with a malevolent scowl.  None the less, he kept
me company.  I had already warned Holmes by telegram of the hour of our
arrival, but we found a message waiting that he was at Lewisham, and

was to find that he was not alone in the sitting-room of our client.  A

grey-tinted glasses and a large Masonic pin projecting from his tie.

in his straining eyes and his twitching features.

The man sprang to his feet with a hoarse scream.  He clawed into the
air with his bony hands.  His mouth was open, and for the instant he
looked like some horrible bird of prey.  In a flash we got a glimpse of
the real Josiah Amberley, a misshapen demon with a soul as distorted as
his body.  As he fell back into his chair he clapped his hand to his
lips as if to stifle a cough.  Holmes sprang at his throat like a
tiger, and twisted his face towards the ground.  A white pellet fell
from between his gasping lips.

annotation:

The old colourman had the strength of a lion in that great trunk of
his, but he was helpless in the hands of the two experienced
man-handlers.  Wriggling and twisting he was dragged to the waiting
cab, and I was left to my solitary vigil in the ill-omened house.  In
less time than he had named, however, Holmes was back, in company with
a smart young police inspector.

had not met Barker, Watson.  He is my hated rival upon the Surrey
shore.  When you said a tall dark man it was not difficult for me to
complete the picture.  He has several good cases to his credit, has he
not, Inspector?"

with reserve.

useful sometimes, you know.  You, for example, with your compulsory
warning about whatever he said being used against him, could never have
bluffed this rascal into what is virtually a confession."

imagine that we had not formed our own views of this case, and that we
would not have laid our hands on our man.  You will excuse us for
feeling sore when you jump in with methods which we cannot use, and so
rob us of the credit."

Addressee: Inspector MacKinnon (a police inspector involved in the case).

myself from now onwards, and as to Barker, he has done nothing save
what I told him."

to ask questions."

the intelligent and enterprising reporter asks you what the exact
points were which aroused your suspicion, and finally gave you a

There must be a disused well somewhere.  Try your luck there."

annotation:
Who is speaking: Sherlock Holmes.

fragment:
"I'll show you first how it was done, and then I will give the
explanation which is due to you, and even more to my long-suffering
friend here, who has been invaluable throughout.  But, first, I would
give you an insight into this man's mentality.  It is a very unusual
one--so much so that I think his destination is more likely to be
Broadmoor than the scaffold.  He has, to a high degree, the sort of
mind which one associates with the mediæval Italian nature rather than
with the modern Briton.  He was a miserable miser who made his wife so
wretched by his niggardly ways that she was a ready prey for any
adventurer.  Such a one came upon the scene in the person of this
chess-playing doctor.  Amberley excelled at chess--one mark, Watson, of
a scheming mind.  Like all misers, he was a jealous man, and his
jealousy became a frantic mania.  Rightly or wrongly, he suspected an
intrigue.  He determined to have his revenge, and he planned it with
diabolical cleverness.  Come here!"

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The narrator, Dr. John Watson, recounting the events in first person.
- Who is addressed: The narration is to the reader; within the scene "us" refers to Watson plus Sherlock Holmes and at least one other companion involved in the investigation (the client or a police officer mentioned earlier).
- What is the topic: Holmes is guiding the party through the house as part of a search for concealed evidence (bodies or hiding-places) connected to the crime; they stop at the open door of the house's strong-room to inspect it.
- Where they are: Inside the house under investigation (Amberley's house, from the preceding context), moving along an internal passage to the strong-room — a locked/secure room used for valuables that is here open for examination.
fragment:
Holmes led us along the passage with as much certainty as if he had
lived in the house, and halted at the open door of the strong-room.

annotation: Spoken by the Inspector (the police detective who has accompanied Holmes and Watson), said aloud to Holmes and Watson as they stand at the open door of Amberley’s strong-room. He is commenting on the strong, unpleasant smell of fresh paint coming from the strong-room.
fragment: "Pooh!  What an awful smell of paint!" cried the Inspector.

annotation:
- Speaker: Sherlock Holmes.
- Addressed to: Dr. Watson and the Inspector (and any policemen present) — Holmes is explaining his reasoning aloud to the group gathered.
- Topic: Holmes outlines the first clue (the strong smell of paint) and how it, together with the existence of a hermetically sealed strong-room, led him to suspect a concealed "guilty" smell; he also explains that he checked the Haymarket Theatre box-office to disprove Amberley’s alibi (the seat numbers show Amberley was not at the theatre), and that he arranged an investigation by sending an agent (with Dr. Watson accompanying him) to a distant village and used Crockford (a clerical directory) to obtain a vicar’s name as part of that ruse.
- Location: Standing in Amberley’s house, at the open door of the strong-room (the locked/iron-doored room that Holmes is examining). 
- Clarifying notes: “Dr. Watson’s observation” refers to Watson’s earlier notices (including the seat number taken for Amberley’s wife); “my Crockford” is Holmes’s reference to Crockford’s directory of clergy; the Inspector’s earlier exclamation about an “awful smell of paint” is the sensory detail Holmes uses as the first clue.
fragment:
"That was our first clue," said Holmes.  "You can thank Dr. Watson's
observation for that, though he failed to draw the inference.  It set
my foot upon the trail.  Why should this man at such a time be filling
his house with strong odours?  Obviously, to cover some other smell
which he wished to conceal--some guilty smell which would suggest
suspicions.  Then came the idea of a room such as you see here with
iron door and shutter--a hermetically sealed room.  Put those two facts
together, and whither do they lead?  I could only determine that by
examining the house myself.  I was already certain that the case was
serious, for I had examined the box-office chart at the Haymarket
Theatre--another of Dr. Watson's bull's-eyes--and ascertained that
neither B thirty nor thirty-two of the upper circle had been occupied
that night.  Therefore, Amberley had not been to the theatre, and his
alibi fell to the ground.  He made a bad slip when he allowed my astute
friend to notice the number of the seat taken for his wife.  The
question now arose how I might be able to examine the house.  I sent an
agent to the most impossible village I could think of, and summoned my
man to it at such an hour that he could not possibly get back.  To
prevent any miscarriage, Dr. Watson accompanied him.  The good vicar's
name I took, of course, out of my Crockford.  Do I make it all clear to
you?"

annotation:
Speaker: the Inspector (a police official).  
Addressed to: Sherlock Holmes (and the small group present, including Dr. Watson).  
Topic: Praise for Holmes's explanation of his deductions — the significance of the smell of paint, the sealed strong‑room, the empty theatre seats that destroyed Amberley's alibi, and Holmes's plan to get into Amberley's house (sending an agent with Watson to an out‑of‑the‑way village).  
Location: In Amberley's house, in the passage beside the open door of the strong‑room.
fragment: "It is masterly," said the Inspector, in an awed voice.

annotation:
- Speaker: Sherlock Holmes.
- Addressed to: the Inspector (and Dr. Watson / any police present).
- Topic: Holmes is describing how he broke into (burgled) Amberley’s house to inspect a locked, iron‑shuttered strong‑room and what he found there — a hidden gas-pipe/tap that opens into the sealed room (via a plaster ceiling rose) so that, if turned on from outside, the room could be flooded with gas and anyone inside asphyxiated.
- Where: standing in (or at least describing) the house in question, pointing out the skirting, corner tap, and the strong‑room/ceiling rose; he is explaining the scene of the attempted murder.
fragment:
"There being no fear of interruption I proceeded to burgle the house.
Burglary has always been an alternative profession, had I cared to
adopt it, and I have little doubt that I should have come to the front.
Observe what I found.  You see the gas-pipe along the skirting here.
Very good.  It rises in the angle of the wall, and there is a tap here
in the corner.  The pipe runs out into the strong-room, as you can see,
and ends in that plaster rose in the centre of the ceiling, where it is
concealed by the ornamentation.  That end is wide open.  At any moment
by turning the outside tap the room could be flooded with gas.  With
door and shutter closed and the tap full on I would not give two
minutes of conscious sensation to anyone shut up in that little
chamber.  By what devilish device he decoyed them there I do not know,
but once inside the door they were at his mercy."

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The Inspector of police (the Scotland Yard detective who has been questioning Holmes).
- Who is addressed: Mr. Sherlock Holmes (the Inspector asks Holmes for his next move).
- Topic: The Inspector is reacting to Holmes's discovery of a gas pipe that vents into a sealed room; he notes an earlier officer had smelled gas but windows/door were then open and painting had been started (possibly to mask odors). He asks Holmes what should be done next in the investigation.
- Where they are: Inside Amberley's house, at the room/strong-room whose skirting and ceiling contain the gas-pipe and the plaster rose Holmes described (the scene of the suspected gas-related crime).
fragment:
The Inspector examined the pipe with interest.  "One of our officers
mentioned the smell of gas," said he, "but, of course, the window and
door were open then, and the paint--or some of it--was already about.
He had begun the work of painting the day before, according to his
story.  But what next, Mr. Holmes?"

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Sherlock Holmes is narrating ("I" = Holmes).
- Who is addressed: He is replying to the Inspector (and those present with him — including Dr. Watson) in the ongoing inquiry.
- What is the topic: Holmes describes an unexpected encounter while breaking into the victim's house — he was climbing out of the pantry window at dawn when he was caught by Mr. Barker, a rival private detective hired by Dr. Ray Ernest's family. Barker had been watching the house, had even suspected Dr. Watson as a suspicious caller, and on seeing someone climbing out he nearly arrested Watson; after Holmes explained the situation they agreed to cooperate.
- Where they are (narration vs. event): Holmes is recounting this episode to the Inspector in their meeting (implied Baker Street). The incident itself took place at Dr. Ray Ernest's house — specifically at the pantry window at dawn.
fragment:
"Well, then came an incident which was rather unexpected to myself.  I
was slipping through the pantry window in the early dawn when I felt a
hand inside my collar, and a voice said: 'Now, you rascal, what are you
doing in there?'  When I could twist my head round I looked into the
tinted spectacles of my friend and rival, Mr. Barker.  It was a curious
forgathering, and set us both smiling.  It seems that he had been
engaged by Dr. Ray Ernest's family to make some investigations, and had
come to the same conclusion as to foul play.  He had watched the house
for some days, and had spotted Dr. Watson as one of the obviously
suspicious characters who had called there.  He could hardly arrest
Watson, but when he saw a man actually climbing out of the pantry
window there came a limit to his restraint.  Of course, I told him how
matters stood and we continued the case together."

annotation:
- Speaker: a member of Dr. Ray Ernest's household (a worried relative present at the scene).
- Addressed to: Sherlock Holmes (and the Inspector/other investigators present).
- Topic: asking why the killer chose that particular victim ("him" = the person lured into the strong‑room and gassed) instead of someone in the family — i.e., why that man was targeted.
- Where: in Dr. Ray Ernest's house, near the pantry/strong‑room where Holmes is pointing out the gas pipe; the inquiry occurs during the on‑site investigation with Holmes, the Inspector, Watson and others present.
fragment: "Why him?  Why not us?"

annotation:
Speaker: Sherlock Holmes.
Addressee: the Inspector (the police officer who has been examining the pipe; Watson is also present).
Topic: Holmes is explaining why he arranged a small staged "test" (a ruse to draw out or confirm the guilty party) and why he used Mr. Barker/the private watcher rather than having the police carry it out — he thought the Inspector would not have pursued such an extreme stratagem.
Location: At the scene of the investigation (Dr. Ray Ernest's house, during the inquiry where the Inspector examined the pipe and Holmes has been recounting the pantry-window incident).
fragment:
"Because it was in my mind to put that little test which answered so
admirably.  I fear you would not have gone so far."

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The previous line ("Because it was in my mind...") is spoken by the narrator, the detective who set up the little test (the investigator explaining his choice).
- Who is addressed: The Inspector — the police officer who had just asked "Why him? Why not us?"
- Topic: Why the detective chose to use a particular man to carry out a test/trap instead of the police doing it themselves.
- Where: In the room where they are reviewing the case (the discussion of the investigation — likely at the house or in the police office where the parties have gathered).
fragment: The Inspector smiled.

annotation:
Speaker: The Inspector (a police officer).  
Addressed to: Mr. Holmes.  
Topic: The Inspector is asking Holmes to withdraw from the investigation and to hand over all his findings/results to the police — referring to a “little test” Holmes had just carried out that yielded decisive evidence.  
Where: In a face-to-face discussion between Holmes and the Inspector during the ongoing investigation (the Inspector had just smiled, so this is a direct conversation at the scene of inquiry or in the room where they are conferring).
fragment:
"Well, maybe not.  I understand that I have your word, Mr. Holmes, that
you step right out of the case now and that you turn all your results
over to us."

annotation:
- Speaker: Sherlock Holmes.
- Addressee: The Inspector (a police official present in the scene).
- Topic: Holmes's reply to the Inspector's demand that Holmes withdraw from the investigation and hand over his findings; Holmes affirms (dryly) that stepping aside and turning over results is his "custom."
- Where: In the presence of the Inspector during their discussion—likely at the police office or wherever the interview is taking place (the exact room isn't specified in the history, only that the Inspector is present and smiling).
fragment: "Certainly, that is always my custom."

annotation:
Speaker: The Inspector (a police officer — likely Inspector Lestrade).  
Addressee: Mr. Sherlock Holmes.  
Topic: The Inspector thanks Holmes, accepts Holmes's assessment that the case is clear, and indicates the police will take charge of handling the bodies and the investigation now that Holmes has promised to hand over his results.  
Where: In the course of the investigation, in the presence of police (at the scene or where police business is being conducted) — the phrase "the Force" signals a policeman speaking.
fragment:
"Well, in the name of the Force I thank you.  It seems a clear case, as
you put it, and there can't be much difficulty over the bodies."

annotation:
Speaker: Sherlock Holmes.  
Addressee: a police inspector present (one of the detectives who had just asked Holmes to leave the case and hand over his results).  
Topic: Holmes is about to reveal a small, telling piece of physical evidence connected with the Amberley case and is coaching the inspector in his method: to imagine himself in the victim's (or perpetrator's) position in order to deduce what would have been done. He sets up a hypothetical — "shut up in this little room with two minutes to live" — to prompt the inspector to think as the trapped person would.  
Location: they are at the crime scene — a "little room" where Amberley (one of the victims) and the other bodies were found; Holmes is pointing out something at the scene that Amberley likely missed.
fragment:
"I'll show you a grim little bit of evidence," said Holmes, "and I am
sure Amberley himself never observed it.  You'll get results,
Inspector, by always putting yourself in the other fellow's place, and
thinking what you would do yourself.  It takes some imagination, but it
pays.  Now, we will suppose that you were shut up in this little room,
had not two minutes to live, but wanted to get even with the fiend who
was probably mocking at you from the other side of the door.  What
would you do?"

annotation:
Speaker: Sherlock Holmes.
Addressee: the police Inspector (referred to as "Inspector" in the preceding lines).
Topic: Holmes is prompting the Inspector to imagine what he would do if trapped with only minutes to live — specifically, to "write a message" as part of a hypothetical stratagem to get even with or deceive the person outside the door. This is part of Holmes's lesson about putting yourself in another's place to deduce actions.
Location: the "little room" mentioned just before — they are imagining being shut up in a small locked room (the same room connected to the Amberley matter).
fragment: "Write a message."

annotation:
- Who is speaking: Sherlock Holmes.
- Who is addressed: an Inspector of police (the investigating officer present).
- What is the topic: Holmes is pointing out a hidden, incomplete dying/message scratched in purple indelible pencil just above the skirting (baseboard) reading "We we----". He explains that a man shut up in the little room would try to leave a message about how he died but might hide it or be interrupted, so the scrawl is a hurried, unfinished attempt to communicate.
- Where they are: at the crime scene — the small locked room where Amberley (the victim) was confined and found; Holmes and the inspector are examining the wall and other evidence.
fragment:
"Exactly.  You would like to tell people how you died.  No use writing
on paper.  That would be seen.  If you wrote on the wall some eye might
rest upon it.  Now, look here!  Just above the skirting is scribbled
with a purple indelible pencil: 'We we----'  That's all."

annotation:
Speaker: Sherlock Holmes.  
Addressee: the Inspector (the police officer present).  
Topic: Holmes is asking for the Inspector's interpretation of the partial message ("We we----") scratched in purple indelible pencil just above the skirting‑board — the "grim little bit of evidence" Holmes has just pointed out.  
Location: the small locked room where Amberley’s body is being examined.
fragment: "What do you make of that?"

annotation:
Speaker: Sherlock Holmes (answering).
Addressee: Dr. John Watson (who asked "What do you make of that?").
Topic: Interpretation of a partial, scrawled dying message — the purple indelible-pencil words "We we----" written just above the skirting board. Holmes concludes the victim was on the floor, grievously wounded and lost consciousness before finishing the message.
Place: At the scene of the death — inside the room where the body lies, examining the wall close to the floor (the skirting board).
fragment:
"Well, it's only a foot above the ground.  The poor devil was on the
floor and dying when he wrote it.  He lost his senses before he could
finish."

annotation:
- Speaker: the investigator who has just examined the scene (the same person who said "Well, it's only a foot above the ground").
- Addressee: the other person in the conversation (the companion who asked "What do you make of that?").
- Topic: the half‑finished inscription found on the wall; the speaker is reporting what the dying man appears to have been trying to write — "We were murdered."
- Where: in the room where the body was found, just above the skirting board, written with a purple indelible pencil while the victim lay on the floor dying.
fragment: "He was writing, 'We were murdered.'"

annotation:
- Who is speaking: One of the investigators/observers at the scene (the same person who just interpreted the scrawled words).
- Who is addressed: A fellow investigator or questioner who asked "What do you make of that?"
- Topic: Interpreting a partial dying message — the speaker agrees it reads "We were murdered" and suggests checking the corpse for an indelible pencil that might have been used to write it.
- Where: At the crime scene, beside the body on the floor (the earlier lines state the writing was a foot above the ground and the victim was on the floor and dying).
fragment: "That's how I read it.  If you find an indelible pencil on the body----"

annotation:
Speaker: a police inspector (speaking as the official in charge of the investigation — likely Lestrade or another policeman).
Addressee: the detective/narrator (Holmes or Watson), the other investigator present.
Topic: they agree to search for an indelible pencil (the possible writing instrument of the dying message) and discuss the strange fact that there was no robbery despite the victim having securities/bonds on his person — the bonds were found and their possession was verified.
Location: at the scene of the murder / where the body is being examined (they are discussing the dying message written on the wall and the corpse).
fragment:
"We'll look out for it, you may be sure.  But those securities?
Clearly there was no robbery at all.  And yet he _did_ possess those
bonds.  We verified that."

annotation:
Speaker: a police officer/inspector (the same person who just said “We’ll look out for it, you may be sure”), addressing Sherlock Holmes (and by extension Dr. Watson).

Topic: speculation about the fate of the missing securities/bonds that belonged to the victim. The inspector suggests that the eloping couple have hidden the bonds safely and that, once the elopement is over, one of them will "discover" and produce the papers — claiming they were returned or accidentally dropped — to cover up their guilt.

Where: in the course of the investigation, just after evidence has been checked — either at the house where the bodies/scene were examined or at the local police office while discussing the case and the verified absence of a robbery.
fragment:
"You may be sure he has them hidden in a safe place.  When the whole
elopement had passed into history he would suddenly discover them, and
announce that the guilty couple had relented and sent back the plunder
or had dropped it on the way."

annotation:
Who is speaking: A police Inspector (a law-enforcement official involved in the investigation).

Who is addressed: The private detective who has been handling the case (the "you" of the conversation — in context, Sherlock Holmes/the detective who made the preceding remarks).

Topic: The Inspector is complimenting the detective on having overcome all the difficulties of the case and is puzzled why the client called the detective instead of relying solely on the police. This follows an earlier exchange about specific evidence (an indelible pencil found on the body) and about missing securities/bonds that someone must have hidden.

Where they are: In a discussion following the investigation — likely at the police station or in a private room where the Inspector and the detective are reviewing evidence and the progress of the case.
fragment:
"You certainly seem to have met every difficulty," said the Inspector.
"Of course, he was bound to call us in, but why he should have gone to
you I can't understand."

annotation:
Who is speaking: Sherlock Holmes ("Holmes answered" in the fragment).
Who is addressed: the Inspector (a Scotland Yard inspector present in the conversation — the same "Inspector" quoted in the preceding lines).
What is the topic: Holmes is explaining the suspect's motive and attitude. They had established that there was no real robbery but that the man did possess the bonds and had staged events around an elopement. Holmes says the man was arrogantly confident — he went so far as to involve the police and even claim to have consulted Sherlock Holmes, thinking that such a show of openness would make him above suspicion.
Where they are: in conversation with the Inspector while discussing the case (the Inspector has just spoken); the scene is the ongoing case discussion (likely in Holmes's rooms or wherever the Inspector was interviewed).

Note: "Pure swank!" = "pure boastful posturing" — Holmes is dismissing the man's pretentiousness and calculated show of innocence.
fragment:
"Pure swank!" Holmes answered.  "He felt so clever and so sure of
himself that he imagined no one could touch him.  He could say to any
suspicious neighbour, 'Look at the steps I have taken.  I have
consulted not only the police, but even Sherlock Holmes.'"

annotation:
- Who is "speaking": This is a narrative line about "the Inspector" — a police inspector (the same inspector who spoke earlier in the exchange, likely Lestrade).
- Who is addressed: He is reacting to Sherlock Holmes; the preceding lines are a back-and-forth between the Inspector and Holmes.
- Topic: They are discussing a man who hid stolen goods during an elopement and tried to appear above suspicion by saying he had consulted the police — even Sherlock Holmes — to give himself an alibi.
- Where: The action takes place where the conversation is occurring (the Inspector and Holmes are together — implied to be Holmes's rooms/sitting-room during their meeting).  
- Note: This line is narration of the Inspector's reaction (a laugh), not a spoken sentence.
fragment: The Inspector laughed.

annotation:
- Who is speaking: The Inspector (the same "Inspector" who laughed in the previous line).
- Who is addressed: Mr. Sherlock Holmes.
- What is the topic: The Inspector pardons Holmes's self‑reference ("even" — i.e., being consulted) and praises Holmes's handling of the matter as a very competent, "workmanlike" piece of detective work.
- Where they are: In the immediate scene of their conversation (Inspector and Holmes are present); the exact room/location is not specified in the fragment.
fragment:
"We must forgive you your 'even,' Mr. Holmes," said he; "it's as
workmanlike a job as I can remember."

annotation:
Speaker: Dr. John H. Watson (the first‑person narrator).  
Addressee: the reader; Watson is narrating the scene and about to quote a newspaper.  
Topic: a bi‑weekly newspaper report (the North Surrey Observer) about the case called "The Haven Horror" — a glowing account headed "Brilliant Police Investigation" whose concluding paragraph Watson is about to reproduce.  
Where: Watson and "my friend" (Sherlock Holmes) are together when Holmes tosses him the paper — most likely in their sitting‑room at 221B Baker Street (their usual rooms).
fragment:
A couple of days later my friend tossed across to me a copy of the
bi-weekly _North Surrey Observer_.  Under a series of flaming
headlines, which began with "The Haven Horror" and ended with
"Brilliant Police Investigation," there was a packed column of print
which gave the first consecutive account of the affair.  The concluding
paragraph is typical of the whole.  It ran thus:

annotation:
- Who is speaking: the voice of a local newspaper (the North Surrey Observer) — an editorial/reporting voice praising the police.
- Who is addressed: the paper's readers/the general public.
- What is the topic: a glowing account of Inspector MacKinnon's detective work in "The Haven Horror" case — noting his deduction about the smell of paint masking the smell of gas, his inference that the strongroom served as a death-chamber, and the subsequent discovery of the victims in a disused well hidden by a dog-kennel.
- Where they are: this is printed in the bi-weekly North Surrey Observer (a local newspaper). In the story context, Dr. Watson has been handed this paper by Sherlock Holmes and is reading the article recounting events at the Haven and the discovery at the well.
fragment:
"The remarkable acumen by which Inspector MacKinnon deduced from the
smell of paint that some other smell, that of gas, for example, might
be concealed; the bold deduction that the strongroom might also be the
death-chamber, and the subsequent inquiry which led to the discovery of
the bodies in a disused well, cleverly concealed by a dog-kennel,
should live in the history of crime as a standing example of the
intelligence of our professional detectives."

annotation:
Speaker: Sherlock Holmes.  
Addressed to: Dr. John H. Watson (the narrator and Holmes's companion).  
Topic: A glowing newspaper account (the North Surrey Observer's report of "The Haven Horror") praising Inspector MacKinnon's police work; Holmes's wry approval of MacKinnon, his instruction to file the clipping in their case archives, and his hint that the full, "true" version of the case may be told by them another time. Tone: tolerant, slightly amused/ironic.  
Location: In Holmes and Watson's rooms (their sitting-room at Baker Street), immediately after Holmes tossed the paper across to Watson.
fragment:
"Well, well, MacKinnon is a good fellow," said Holmes, with a tolerant
smile.  "You can file it in our archives, Watson.  Some day the true
story may be told."
